course_title: Critical Thinking & Scientific Writing in Animal & Veterinary Biosciences

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate a structured, evidence-based approach to scientific writing, ensuring relevant literature citation and organisation of arguments.
Show evidence of a developing command and understanding of relevant concepts and disciplines.
Apply increasing understanding of your topic to refining and developing your literature review.
Analyse and evaluate a broad range of literature on your topic and draw objective conclusions and/or identify gaps in current knowledge.
Professionally present the literature review in terms of style, formatting, presenting relevant tables and figures and editing, to a standard appropriate for Journal submission.

assessments.task_description:
The student will submit a literature review outline (Part A) and workflow plan (Part B). This will be worth 20% of the final mark for VETS6640. Please ensure you have read the full task description for the Literature Review assessment Task (55%) before undertaking this assessment. This task is a planning tool for the larger written task.

The Outline (PartA)

1.     Follow the recommended literature review outline structure and format in the SVS Hons Handbook, available on Blackboard

2.     Have 1-2 paragraphs of referenced, well written introduction to set the scope and background.

3.     Have a short summary (bullet points are acceptable in the outline document) summarising the content of each subsequent section (excluding references).

4.     The outline should be NO MORE than two pages.

5.     Outline formatting should be the same as the final review (font, line spacing, headings and subheading structure). 

The workflow plan (Part B) should be an agreed workflow for the semester between supervisor and student, noting critical milestones against the weeks of semester. This should be presented as a Gantt chart, with a table describing each milestone using the SMART goals format as a template for writing the milestone statement. The workplan should include scheduled, regular meetings with supervisors (suggest weekly as a minimum) and be aligned and integrated with the developed of the sections of the literature review identified in the outline document. Templates will be provided on Blackboard in the resources folder.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

Please refer to the SVS Hons Handbook, available on Blackboard, for more details of this task and the marking rubric.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit your Assessment through the course Turnitin submission point in Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Task instructions

The Honours Authenticity Report must be submitted by the principal supervisor during the week prior to the Literature Review submission. This is a Pass/Fail hurdle assessment item.

To pass, students must demonstrate to their supervisor a detailed understanding of their written submission. The report, combined with supervisor oversight, is intended to verify and document the student’s comprehension of the topic and scientific principles in their Literature Review.

Supervisor Sign-Off and Support

As this is a Pass/Fail assessment, if a supervisor is unwilling to sign the authenticity report, the student must provide evidence to justify an override by the Honours Program Coordinator. Students are advised to:

  • Keep minutes from supervisory meetings.
  • Save copies of draft documents at each stage using UQ’s Research Data Manager (RDM).

If a student feels they are not receiving adequate or agreed-upon support from their supervisor, they should contact the Honours Program Coordinator at f.shapter@uq.edu.au as soon as possible.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This document must be emailed to the course coordinator, by the principal supervisor, in the week prior to submission of the Literature Review.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Honours students are required to prepare and submit a Literature Review on a topic that is related to their research project by the end of their first semester of enrolment, as the Literature Review assists in the development of the Thesis. The format of the Literature Review may vary according to the nature of the field (experimental, theoretical, comparative, descriptive, etc), but its purpose is the same in all fields. It should be on a topic that is relevant to the Honours research question being asked in VETS6616, VETS6617, VETS6628 or VETS6629, but should not be the same as the actual Literature Review of the Honours Thesis. For example, the topic could be related to a particular set of methodologies that are required to conduct the research project, such as hormone assays or nutritional analyses. The review should summarise salient findings, arguments, theories and other developments.

This assessment task is linked with the Honours Assessment Authenticity Report.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools. This will be assessed through the assessment authentication form and supervisor evaluation.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit your Assessment through the course Turnitin submission point in Blackboard.

assessments.task_description: The supervisor evaluation form is available in the Honours Handbook and on Blackboard, and should be reviewed collaboratively by the supervisor(s) and students within week one of candidature, so all parties are clear about the marking criteria. This is a semester-long evaluation of student performance and growth as an independent researcher.
assessments.submission_guidelines: To be completed and emailed to Course Coordinator, by the Supervisor(s), by the due date for the Literature Review.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.
